- A series of protests hit Jakarta and some of them turned violent with, tragically, one reported casualty. We believe the likelihood of more protests in the near-term is high.- So far, we see limited concrete steps from the government to appease protesters at a time when economic conditions are weak and household sentiment is fragile.- We see the risk of more short-run populist measures, a dimming of reform prospects, a possible delay of another 25bp cut we expect by Bank Indonesia (BI) in September.- FX strategy: We lower the conviction level on short USD/IDR to 3/5 (from 4) because of the near-term risk that the protests may escalate. However, if the situation eases in the near-term, we believe IDR could reverse some of the relative underperformance.
This week, a series of protests took place in Jakarta and across the nation. Some have escalated into clashes with the police, specifically:

- On Monday (25 August), hundreds of Indonesians took to the streets in front of the parliament building to protest against the new monthly IDR50mn (USD3k) housing allowance for parliament members (as compensation for no longer receiving official housing). Protesters reportedly attempted to break metal and concrete barriers, prompting the police to respond with tear gas and water cannons. In addition, the Jakarta Legal Aid Institute (LBH) estimated that 370 individuals, who participated in the protest were arrested, among them were students. The protest appears to have been organized via messaging and social media channels, urging the public to highlight issues such as tax increases, rising national debt, and worsening inequality.

- On Thursday (28 August), labor unions also held mass protests across the country, with larger numbers but were relatively peaceful. The president of the Labor Party said that about 5k people attended the protest in front of the parliament building in Jakarta, and the rest were spread across the nation. The protesters made six demands: (1) increase the 2026 minimum wage by 8.5-10%, (2) stop layoffs and eliminate outsourcing, (3) implement labor tax reform, (4) pass a new labor law without the Omnibus Law, (5) pass the Asset Seizure Bill, and (6) revise the Election Law and redesign the 2029 election system. In addition, workers also raised similar concerns as students over the parliament housing allowance. No clashes were reported and police seemed to have exercised restraint following Jakarta Police Chief Inspector urging personnel to prioritize "a patient approach, and not to be provoked."

However, after the workers dispersed, students from various campuses arrived, continuing the protest. They demanded the dissolution of parliament and the cancellation of excessive parliamentary allowances. By Thursday night, some clashes with the police were reported. An online motorcycle taxi (ojol) driver tragically passed away after reportedly being run over by a police tactical vehicle. The incident was caught on camera and went viral on social media, reportedly sparking public outrage. National Police Chief General Listyo Sigit Prabowo apologized and expressed regret for the incident. The police also reportedly questioned seven members of the police that hit the ojol driver.
Another round of protests on Friday (29 August) occurred, led by the Student Executive Body Alliance of Indonesia (BEM SI). The students urged the public to take to the streets

to protest against police force brutality in dealing with the demonstrations in front of the parliament building on Thursday. Some student representatives expressed concerns that more casualties will occur if this incident is allowed to pass without consequences. [13] On Friday evening, clashes between protesters and the police were also reported. Clashes were also reported in other big cities across the country other than Jakarta, such as Surabaya, Medan, and Bandung (Source: Bloomberg).

In a video released by the Presidential Secretariat on Friday afternoon (29 August), President Prabowo expressed his condolences over the tragic death of the ojo/ driver. He also pledged to ensure the well- being of the victim's family, saying "we will pay special attention to their parents and siblings." He ordered a thorough and transparent investigation into the case. [14] He also urged the nation to "remain calm and maintain trust in his administration." [15]

Separately, on Thursday evening, State Secretary Prasetyo Hadi said that a Task Force on Layoffs and a Labor Welfare Council will soon be formed, which is, however, not new, as this plan was already announced by the President during the commemoration of International Workers' Day in Jakarta on 1 May. [16] [17] He explained that these two institutions are crucial for addressing the challenges by workers. However, he did not confirm whether the government would meet workers' demands for an \(8.5 - 10\%\) increase in the minimum wage next year. [18]

Meanwhile, parliament clarified that lawmakers will only receive the monthly housing allowance until October this year, but critics have called for transparency over the policy, with them saying the allowance is "excessive" and "insensitive". [19]

We think these protests bear close monitoringWe think these protests bear close monitoring, as we believe there is a risk that tensions could remain high in the coming days because of the reported casualty, which could spark more widespread public anger. In the afternoon of 29 August, thousands of ride- hailing motorcyclists joined the funeral march of Affan Kurniawan, who died during the protests on Thursday and based on videos shared by the media, the march was going through parts of Jakarta's main thoroughfares. [20] By contrast, during the demonstrations in August last year, no major incidents of violence were reported and the protests eased after a few days, when parliament relented and decided to withdraw the proposed election law revisions (see First Insights - Indonesia: The risk of further protests in the near term have likely declined materially, 26 August 2024).

This week's protests are also happening at a time when economic conditions are weaker than last year and headlines of job losses have persisted, already weighing on household sentiment, as we argued before (see Asia Insights - Indonesia: Why weak consumption is likely to linger and more policy support is needed, 24 August 2025). The protests may also thus reflect growing public discontent despite the policy priorities of the Prabowo- administration on social assistance programs (e.g. the flagship free nutritious meal program, 3 million housing, village cooperatives etc). Further out, key demands of protesters may be difficult to meet, in our view. For example, legislating a new labor law may take time and raising wages may also be detrimental to businesses which, as we have noted, are also facing weak demand conditions (see Asia Insights - Indonesia: Postcard from Jakarta, 18 August 2025).

From fiscal policy perspective, we see the risk of more short- run populist measures, at a time when deliberations in parliament are ongoing for budget 2026 (see First Insights - Indonesia: A lower fiscal deficit proposed in Budget 2026 looks difficult to meet, 16 August 2025). As such, this could add to spending pressures and the overall fiscal deficit. Importantly, if protests are prolonged, these could limit prospects of structural reforms, particularly on labor market legislation, for which there is already some uncertainty over it being implemented after the Omnibus Law for Job Creation, which we argued was a landmark legislation to help liberalize labor markets and attract FDI, was rendered unconstitutional on 31 October 2024 (see Asia Insights - Indonesia: Uncertainty in labor market regulations rising sharply again, 3 December 2024). In terms of monetary policy, we see a rising risk of a delay in the 25bp cut we forecast by BI in September if balance of payments pressures persist as a result of increased political uncertainty due to the protests.

We maintain our short USD/IDR trade, though lower the covidion to 3/5 (previously 4/5), targeting 15,500 by end- October. While there remains local uncertainty over protests, we believe USD/IDR should trend lower in the medium- term because: 1) the impact of previous protests on IDR has been limited and short- lived. In previous examples of protests, depreciation pressures on IDR have been limited. 2) BI has remained active in the FX market, stabilizing the currency with interventions in FX spot, bond, domestic, and offshore NDF. Thus, a move higher in USD/IDR will likely be capped by BI. 3) Portfolio flows into Indonesia have been positive with MTD August equity inflows of USD744mn (1- 28 August), and bond inflows (1- 27August) of USD791mn; and 4) Powell was relatively dovish at the Jackson Hole symposium, which would likely keep the USD softer.
